title: 112_hr4020
content: The Act titled "Flood Insurance for Farmers Act of 2012" establishes floodplain management criteria. The Flood Insurance for Farmers Act of 2012 amends the National Flood Insurance Act to provide criteria for land management and use regarding the construction of agricultural structures in areas with special flood hazards. The Flood Insurance for Farmers Act of 2012 amends the National Flood Insurance Act to provide criteria for construction of agricultural structures in special flood hazard areas. Criteria for structures in levee-protected areas allow new construction without restrictions and require the lowest floor for substantial improvements to existing residential structures. The Flood Insurance for Farmers Act of 2012 amends the National Flood Insurance Act to provide criteria for construction of agricultural structures in special flood hazard areas. The structure must have the lowest floor elevated to or above the base flood level, except for existing structures in legacy communities protected by levees. Substantial damage is defined as the cost of restoring the structure to its before-damaged condition equaling or exceeding 100 percent of the market value before the damage occurred. The criteria for construction of agricultural structures in special flood hazard areas under the Flood Insurance for Farmers Act of 2012 allow for repair, restoration, or replacement of structures in legacy communities protected by levees. Definitions for terms like "agricultural structure" and "covered levee-protected area" are provided. The term 'covered levee-protected area' refers to an area protected by a levee without accreditation, providing at least 1 foot of freeboard above the base flood water level. A 'legacy community' is defined as a community with a population under 2,000, historically reliant on agriculture for its economy. This definition applies to exceptions for agricultural structures in special flood hazard areas. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to include provisions related to structures in flood-prone areas. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to include provisions related to structures in flood-prone areas, focusing on the availability of flood insurance coverage and chargeable rates. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to provide flood insurance coverage for new construction and substantial improvement of agricultural structures in flood hazard areas, based on chargeable premium rates. The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 is amended to provide flood insurance coverage for structures in covered levee-protected areas upon request. Coverage will be available at chargeable premium rates applicable to low or moderate risk flooding areas. Task Force on Legacy Community Flood Insurance Issues established. Task Force established by the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Secretary of Agriculture to study challenges faced by legacy communities in flood hazard areas for the national flood insurance program. Membership includes representatives from farm, financial, and floodplain management organizations. The Task Force established by the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Secretary of Agriculture includes representatives from various organizations and individuals with expertise in flood hazard areas for the national flood insurance program. Membership criteria include representatives from national organizations, agricultural commodities organizations, State representatives, flood control associations, elected officials from local governments, and individuals with expertise in flood-related issues. The Task Force, co-chaired by the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Secretary of Agriculture, will not receive compensation but will have travel expenses covered. Staff from these agencies may be detailed to assist the Task Force. A report is due within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The Task Force, co-chaired by the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Secretary of Agriculture, will submit a report to the Committees on Financial Services and Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs regarding a study on recommended changes to the national flood insurance program for legacy communities with a population of less than 2,000 and based on agricultural production. The Task Force, co-chaired by the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the Secretary of Agriculture, will submit a report on recommended changes to the national flood insurance program for legacy communities with a population of less than 2,000 based on agricultural production. The task force will terminate after 120 days from the report submission.
